element.name: Beads of Contemplation
element.description: This strand of eight wooden beads, each cleverly carved with geometric patterns, hangs from a stout length of cording. The beads store ki energy placed into them, holding the ki until you use it. The beads can store up to 8 ki points. At the end of a resting, you can place ki energy into the beads by touching them and expending a number of ki points equal to half your proficiency bonus. While wearing or carrying the beads, you can use a bonus action to remove any number of ki points from the beads, regaining that amount of ki points and freeing up space in the beads.

element.name: Campaign Field Tent
element.description: You can use an action to place this 1-inch cloth cube on the ground and speak its command word. The cube rapidly grows into a field tent with open or closed sides (your choice) that remains until you use an action to speak the command word that dismisses it, which works only if the tent is empty. The field tent is a canvas tent, 15 feet on a side and 10 feet high. It remains firmly fixed to the ground, even when standing on bare stone, a ship's deck, or loose sand, and its magic prevents it from being tipped over. Each creature in the area where the tent appears must make a DC 15 Dexterity saving throw, taking 5d10 bludgeoning damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. In either case, the creature is pushed to an unoccupied space outside but next to the tent. Objects in the area that aren't being worn or carried take this damage and are pushed automatically. The tent has 50 hit points, immunity to nonmagical attacks, excluding siege weapons, and resistance to all other damage. The tent contains a small table with a chair and five simple beds made of cloth and foldable wooden frames. The field tent can hold up to six Medium or smaller creatures. When a creature finishes a resting in the tent, it regains double the hit points from any Hit Dice it spends. When a creature finishes a resting in the tent, it reduces its exhaustion level by 2 instead of 1. In addition, a creature has advantage on saving throws it makes against disease and poison while it rests in the tent.

element.name: Chain Cilice
element.description: This bracelet made of spiked chain is designed to fit around the ankle, wrist, or thigh. While wearing the cilice, you can use an action to speak its command word, causing it to tighten on your skin and dealing 1d6 piercing damage to you at the start of each of your turns until you use a bonus action to end it. If you have the Ki class feature or ki points from another source, such as the Inner Resilience feat, you regain 1 ki point for every 5 damage caused by the cilice. If the cilice would reduce you to 0 hit points, it reduces you to 1 hit point instead and the effect ends. If the cilice's effect was ended in this way, it can't be used again until the next dawn.

element.description: One or more thin bands of flexible, pale blue crystal run along this plain, brown leather belt. As an action, you can pour a potion onto a band of crystal, which absorbs the potion and turns a deep blue. Each band of crystal can store only one potion at a time. This belt contains only one band of crystal. While wearing the belt, you can use an action to speak the belt's command word and gain the benefits of the potion as if you drank it.

sheet.description: This ordinary bag, made from cured animal hide, appears empty. Reaching inside the bag, however, reveals the presence of a number of flat, bone tiles. The bag weighs 1/2 pound. You can use an action to pull one of the tiles from the bag and throw it into the air in front of you. The tile floats 5 feet off the ground and displays a runic symbol. Make a DC 12 Wisdom check. The symbol on the tile is upright on a successful save, and it is reversed on a failed save. Roll a d12 and consult the appropriate table to determine the rune's effect. If a result requires a saving throw, the DC is 15. The tile vanishes after it displays a rune, but the bag never runs out of tiles. Once used, the bag shouldn't be used again until the next dawn. Each time it is used again before then, the DC of the Wisdom check increases by 5 for each tile drawn after the first. You can be affected by more than one rune's effect at a time. element.name: Soulbound Wraps

When you hit a creature with an unarmed strike while wearing these wraps, you can choose to reduce the damage you deal by up to 10, pulling some of the energy of the hit back into you through the wraps. You regain 1 ki point for every 10 damage you choose not to deal to a creature you hit. Once you regain a number of ki points equal to half your proficiency bonus, the wraps unravel and can't be worn again until the next dawn.

element.name: Stasis Stone
element.description: This small, crystalline, purple stone measures 3/4 of an inch in diameter and weighs an ounce. Typically, 1d4 + 2 stasis stones can be found together. You can use an action to throw the stone up to 30 feet. The stone explodes on impact and is destroyed. Each creature within a 10-foot radius of where the stone landed must succeed on a DC 15 Constitution saving throw or be petrified until the end of its next turn as the stone releases temporal magic and freezes it in time.

It regains all expended charges daily at dawn. You can expend 1 of its charges to give yourself advantage on weapon attacks for 1 minute. When you roll a 20 on an attack roll made with a weapon, you can expend 1 charge to move up to your speed without provoking opportunity attack. You must be within 5 feet of the banner to expend any of its charges.
